newsitem.title: USA: USDA hopes to meet with Egypt Sunday on biotech.
newsitem.headline: USDA hopes to meet with Egypt Sunday on biotech.

text.p: U.S. Agriculture Department officials hope to meet with Egyptian government officials Sunday to discuss a decree that would bar imports of genetically-altered commodities, a USDA official said Friday.

"We think there must be some confusion because this is kind of an unusual action to take out of the blue and there are serious implications," said USDA trade adviser Paul Drazek. "Hopefully we will be able to straighten it out fairly easily."
Drazek said the Egyptians had never indicated concerns about biotechnology or U.S. grain.
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman also downplayed media reports about the situation.

"Obviously, we would have great concern if the story were true as reported. But I have a feeling it did not come from the highest levels of government," he told Reuters after opening a farmers' market at the Energy Department.

The Egyptian Health Ministry has issued a decree that it will require imports of commodities meant for human consumption to be accompanied by proof that genetic engineering was not used in their production. The news seeped out after traders were given a copy of the order, dated July 1, this week.

Egypt is a big customer of U.S. corn, a crop that has been heavily planted to gene-altered seed. It ranked as the No. 6 buyer last year. So far in the 1996-97 marketing year, Egypt has purchased 2.3 million tonnes of U.S. corn.
